params.text:
DISEASE MANAGEMENT

 

1. Damping – off

Tissues of the papaya seedling stem at the solid line become water-soaked and rotten due to infection by one or more species of fungi-like Pithium debayranum, Pytopthora palmivora and Rhizoctonia sp. It is common in the nursery or in the field where seedlings are too crowded. It is favored by high temperature and wet weather.

Control measures: 

  • Avoid overcrowding of seedlings. 

  • Provide good drainage and adequate soil erosion. 

  • Practice proper plant spacing and depth of planting.

 

2. Papaya mosaic

The leaves of infected plants develop a wrinkled and rough appearance. Younger leaves are generally stunted and chlorotic and are accompanied by vein-banding or transparent oil that are scattered over the leaf veins. The older and mature leaves show more pronounced chlorotic areas and are stunted. Severe attack results in stunting of petioles. Infected young fruit shows small, dark green spots, which appear either on the stem or blossom end. They enlarge as the fruit develops. Mottling of green and brownish rings appears.

Control measures: 

  • Cut down infected plant immediate

  • Dispose by burning.


3. Bacterial Crown Rot

Diseased papaya is distinguished in the field by the dropping leaves which results from infection of the petiole or stem with the bacterium Erwina cariceae or E. papayae.

Control measures: 

  • Eradicate severely infested plants and disinfect tools with 10% formalin solution.

  • In cases when the stem is not infected, remove only the infected petioles and leaves.

  • Spray crown (petioles, leaves, fruit and young stem) with copper fungicide at 3 g/li. of water once every 14 day to protect the papaya plants during rainy periods.

 

4. Anthracnose

The disease is caused by Collectrichum gleosporiodes and affects not only the fruits but also petioles of older leaves.

Control Measures: 

  • Spray with recommended fungicide at 7-10-day interval

  • Use a spreader sticker to ensure good spray coverage. 

  • Treat fruits in hot water at temperature of 110- 120°F for 20 minutes to reduce post-harvest storage decay.

 

5. Pythoptora rot

Seedling damps-off, root rots, trunk cankers and fruit rots. Immature fruits are attacked through wounds while mature fruits at any location.

Control measures: 

  • Remove infected fruit.

  • Dispose properly infected fruit.

  • Spray copper fungicide at recommended rate. 

  • For fruits in storage, control by hot water dips at 46.7°F for 20 minutes then cool with running tap water.

 

6. Papaya Ringspot Virus (PRSV) 

This is readily transmitted mechanically by sap. It is also stylet born and insect transmitted by aphids. It is not readily transmitted through seed.

Control measures: 

 

  • Eradicate infested plants by:

 

  1. Spraying the infected plant and healthy tree surrounding it with appropriate insecticide.

  2. Uproot and chop the infected trees to small pieces. 

  3. Place the chopped plant debris in a sack or plastic bag and burn it in a suitable place.

 

  • Never intercrop papaya trees with possible alternate host such as watermelon, cucumber, squash, among others

  • Enforce quarantine measures prohibiting the transfer and introduction of papaya and alternate hosts from affected orchards to new growing areas.

  • Use resistant papaya cultivars.
